description:
A happy marriage is not so much how compatible you are but how you deal with incompatibility during times of trouble and conflicts. üë©üèª‚Äç‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüíã‚Äçüë®üèºü§ç

It is inevitable for David and I to have disagreements sometimes but it is how we resolve them that matters. 10% of conflicts are due to difference of opinions. 90% are due to the hostility of voice and passive aggressive body language. 

Here are 5 simple but effective ways on how we try to resolve our marriage conflicts......

1) Give each other a chance to talk uninterrupted.
2) Listen to each other without judgement.
3) Use affirming words like " I feel...." and " I hear you" instead of " You are always like that."
4) Pray together.
5) Don't be afraid to say the magic words...." I'm sorry and I love you!"üòå

But if you are facing deeper relationship or family issues, I will strongly encourage you to seek professional help as early as you can.

The Ministry of Social and Family Development, @msfcares has worked with the Community Psychology Hub (CPH) to provide an online counselling service for people facing marital, divorce, parenting, and/or family issues.

You can access CPH‚Äôs online counselling service through the new Family Assist portal (https:// go.gov.sg/onlinecounselling). This portal also provides information, resources and tips on decision making processes, not just for divorce, but also for reconciliation, or strengthening your marriage.

Marriage is about being a team. The harder you work together to make your marriage work, the stronger and healthier your relationship becomes. 

Love is not about how many years, months and days you have been together. It‚Äôs about how much you love, honour and cherish each other every single day.  Âä†Ê≤πÔºÅ
üí™üèΩüí™üèΩ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

I, an optimist. He, a pessimist.‚Å£
I, an instant gratifier. He, a planner.‚Å£
I, am spontaneous. He, needs a routine.‚Å£
Opposite attracts. But it takes very hard work to make them complement.‚Å£
‚Å£
I, a dreamer. He, a realist.‚Å£
I, easily contented. He, a perfectionist.‚Å£
I, a whiner. He, a diverter.‚Å£
Fairy tales are just, well, fairy tales.‚Å£
Read them with a pinch of salt!‚Å£
‚Å£
Don't compare your mundane BTS to our curated reel - The journey to a lasting matrimony will have its highs & lows, peace & storms. It's easier to say "I Do" after falling in love, than to say "I Still Do" after being married for some time, the latter requires a hell lot of continued commitment. But our promise to love & care for each other is everlasting, right?‚Å£
‚Å£
So to celebrate our dedication in nurturing long-lasting, harmonious marriages, the 6th installment of „ÄäI Still Do„Äãis back! An annual campaign organised by Families For Life (FFL) to celebrate love, commitment, & marriage, look out for enriching online programmes, useful resources, & fun bonding activites for married couples, happening right now till 13 Mar!‚Å£
‚Å£
"I Still Do 2022" also presents its 1st digital card game, 10 Moments of Love, specially created activity to spark meaningful conversations between couples. A variant of the game is also available as an IGS filter @FamiliesForLife IG.‚Å£
‚Å£
Play with either, or both! And stand to win attractive prizes, including the grand prizes of a 2D1N Staycation @GrandHyattSing with complimentary breakfast & dinner for 2, worth $704++ (FB) &¬†a 3.5carat natural Tourmaline gemstone with store credits, worth $2,300 (IG)!‚Å£
‚Å£
Now, we said marriage is hard work, right?‚Å£
For a more informative way to enhance marital & familial relationships, or to gain personalised insights of strength & growth areas in your relationships, also check out Marriage Preparation Programme (MPP, more suited for soon-to-weds & newly-weds), Marriage Enrichment Programme (MEP, for married couples) & more bite-sized marriage tips on FFL FB/ IG/ ‚ÄúI Still Do‚Äù/ LifeSG/ ROM/ ROMM sites!‚Å£

[Meet the parenting program that could change your world] How many times do you recall from your childhood being told ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs not that bad‚Äô, ‚ÄòStop crying‚Äô, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre overreacting!‚Äô ‚Äî it‚Äôs distressing and does not support the development of ‚Äòfelt security‚Äô, something we all need, regardless of our family culture or experiences of being parented. #circleofsecurity
.
‚ÄúAs a psychologist, I can tell you that I see in the counselling room the damage this can do across a lifetime. Adults young and old suppressing feelings and needs in relationships (and life) to the point they are so incredibly depressed and unhappy they finally see a professional. Often, people disengage from their emotional selves, pushing loved ones away when they need them most and even explode with anger because so much resentment has built.
.
Sure, mental health isn‚Äôt black and white, and people‚Äôs brains are different. However, a lot of the suffering I see in my therapeutic work can be linked to behaviour patterns in relationships. Patterns of people-pleasing, not asking for help and not telling people how they feel for fear of being dismissed, shamed or rejected.
.
The Circle of Security (COS) Parenting program @circleofsecurity changed the way I saw my daughter, the way I interpreted her less-cooperative behaviours, or her being upset about things that didn‚Äôt seem like such a big deal‚Äîto me. It really helped me to see her respectfully as her own person, with her own valid responses to things without trying to change what she was feeling.‚Äù
.
COS takeaways:
‚Ä¢ Seeing behaviour as connection seeking rather that attention seeking.
‚Ä¢ Holding a sense that your child is good even when they are ‚Äòmisbehaving‚Äô.
‚Ä¢ Responding to anger and strong emotions (yours and theirs!)
‚Ä¢ Letting go of labels like- ‚Äòneedy‚Äô demanding, attention seeking, a problem child.
‚Ä¢ Learning about and managing your emotional triggers.
‚Ä¢ How to find that balance of being firm and loving.
‚Ä¢ Considering a parenting approach without punishments and time outs.
.
Via https://hercanberra.com.au/life/family/meet-the-parenting-program-that-could-change-your-world/
.
The Psychology Practice

One beneficiary is 81-year-old Mr Yiang.

description:
[what does the research say about Men (and Women)?] Researchers from Murdoch University have found that not being able to see someone clearly is no deterrent for a male suitor, whereas women prefer to err on the side of caution.
.
Co-author Kortnee Evans, also from Murdoch, said they discovered that when making judgments based on incomplete information, such as when you can‚Äôt see a person clearly ‚Äì as might occur in a nightclub or bar ‚Äì men, on average, overperceived women‚Äôs attractiveness.
.
‚ÄúWomen, on the other hand, did the opposite ‚Äì when they viewed men under conditions of uncertainty, on average they tended to underestimate the men‚Äôs attractiveness,‚Äù Ms Evans said.
.
Senior Lecturer in Social Psychology Dr Lewis said the findings were important because first impressions can influence decision-making, including whether people decide to interact with someone or not.
.
Via @murdochuniversity @ https://www.murdoch.edu.au/news/articles/forget-beer-goggles-men-overestimate-attractiveness-anyway
.

Our date night topic:¬†Family Abuse

Have you witnessed parents physically abusing their children? Or spouses hurling insults at one another in public? How can we remain vigilant and pick up on cases of family abuse before things go too far?

James and I believe that love should be at the root in all we do and so we talked about how this belief needs to be reflected in our parenting.

In the case of spousal abuse, a couple could appear loving and stable on the outside but be in an emotionally and physically abusive relationship behind closed doors. Apart from physical abuse, it could be verbal insults, put downs, over-controlling behaviour, non-consensual sexual advances or even financial oppression.

With the surge in abuse cases in recent times, we need to step out of our shells, come forward to intervene and no longer view it as a ‚Äúprivate matter‚Äù. Family violence is real and prevalent in our society and we need to work together to stand against it, and stop it.

The Break The Silence campaign by the Ministry of Social and Family development @msfcares aims to raise awareness of family violence and encourages bystanders to safely step in and intervene if they come across cases of family violence.

Many victims could be suffering in silence without a safe way to reach out for help. The ‚ÄúSignal for Help‚Äù hand gesture (swipe this carousel) provides victims a discreet way of showing that they need help, and bystanders seeing this gesture should offer their assistance.

Learn how to identify the gesture and what to do in the event you witness family violence. Head over to¬†http://www.msf.gov.sg/breakthesilence¬†to read up more!

#BreakTheSilence
#SignalforHelp
#StopFamilyViolence

Family means everything to me.

I work hard every day with one goal in mind, to provide for my family.

It‚Äôs heartbreaking to hear that ever since the Covid-19 pandemic hit, there has been a great rise in the number of abuse cases, especially during the circuit breaker period.

I‚Äôve partnered up with the Ministry of Social & Family Development @msfcares to spread the message about the Break The Silence campaign which aims to raise awareness about family violence.

If you are married or in a committed relationship, spousal abuse can come in the form of:

‚óè Physical Abuse: slapping, shoving, punching, wrongful confinement
‚óè Emotional and Psychological Abuse: verbal insults and put-downs, accuse you of something you did not do, controlling your finances or who you meet
‚óè Sexual Abuse: forcing sexual activities onto you, unwanted sexual advances and harassment such as fondling and groping

Family violence is not just a private matter and everyone has a duty to stop it.

With the Signal for Help hand gesture, we hope to create a medium for victims to break the silence & seek help in a safe manner. Raising awareness & understanding this important gesture will allow family members, friends & even bystanders to step in and intervene if they come across any cases of abuse.

For more information, please visit:

www.msf.gov.sg/breakthesilence

#BreakTheSilence
#SignalforHelp
#StopFamilyViolence

A happy and healthy relationship with our spouse and family reflects on our faces. 
Nikhil and I have been married for more than 18 years now with our share of ups and downs, but a good understanding and respect has always helped us both!

But then it is not the same with every couple around. Family violence , comes in various forms such as physical abuse, emotional/ psychological abuse, sexual abuse or even financial abuse.

 We need to understand that it can affect anyone and it is time to #BreakTheSilence.

I have partnered with the Ministry of Social and Family Development @msfcares to spread the message about the Break The Silence campaign which aims to raise awareness about family violence, and encourage bystanders to lend help if anyone is experiencing family violence.

If you are married or in a committed relationship, you could be experiencing spousal abuse with these signs and symptoms:
‚Ä¢ Physical: slapping, shoving, punching, wrongful confinement
‚Ä¢ Emotional and Psychological: verbal insults and put-downs, accuse you of something you did not do, controlling your finances or who you meet
‚Ä¢ Sexual: forcing sexual activities onto you, unwanted sexual advances and harassment
such as fondling and groping

Through the Signal for Help, victims are able to ask for help in a safe and discreet manner. Anyone who sees someone using the gesture, please respond by:
‚Ä¢ Asking general ‚Äúyes‚Äù or ‚Äúno‚Äù questions to reduce risk and make it easier for them to respond 
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt respond immediately, whether physical or online
‚Ä¢ Only reach out by using another form of communication (text, Whatsapp, social media, email etc)
For more information, please visit www.msf.gov.sg/breakthesilence.

#BreaktheSilence #SignalforHelp #StopFamilyViolence #Mums_Babies

description:
Can‚Äôt believe that in the blink of an eye, we are celebrating our fourth wedding anniversary this month. These four years have been filled with wonderful memories, but also difficult conversations, tears, disagreements, which eventually always ended with hugs. Thankfully. 

Marriage is filled with responsibilities, home, children... It can feel like too much to shoulder sometimes. If you‚Äôre facing challenges in your marriage, feel helpless, seeking reconciliation, or considering divorce, you can find information, resources and tips on Family Assist. Family Assist is an online resource portal that provides support for couples looking to strengthen their marriage or find help on any marital issues. You will be able to find tips on building a strong marriage. The portal will also provide tips on how to better manage conflicts.

If you and your spouse have decided to proceed with a divorce, you will be able to find information on how to co-parent after divorce, and how a divorce can impact your children, housing options and finances. The Budget Calculator on the portal can help you better understand how divorce may stretch or strain your finances. You can also sign up for the Mandatory Parenting Programme (MPP), and find information and resources to help you and your family during this period of transition.

You can speak to a counsellor online and seek support through a free-of-charge online counselling service by the Community Psychology Hub, in collaboration with @msfcares. This service allows for anonymous sign-ups so you can be rest assured that your privacy will not be compromised. 

If you are facing marital, divorce and/or co-parenting difficulties, you may want to visit Family Assist at https://familyassist.msf.gov.sg. Alternatively, if you know anyone facing similar difficulties, you may also want to share about the portal with them.

Having a great partner in this union is what ultimately makes the marriage work. Grateful for you, @weipei88. I love how we always overcome our differences with lots of compromise and communication. Lots and lots of it. Happy 4th anniversary, baobi!

#FamilyAssist #CPHonlinecounselling #SingaporeTogether #SGUnite

description:
[I‚Äôm in pain but why is my GP suggesting a psychologist? ü§î] What‚Äôs the link between emotion and my perception of pain?
.
‚ÄúPain, depression, and anxiety travel through similar pathways along your nervous system and share many of the same biological mechanisms. One of the areas in the brain that receives pain signals ‚Äî specifically, the limbic region ‚Äî shares many of the same messengers as the mood signals. We know from research studies using neuroimaging that the parts of the brain controlling emotion and sensory features of pain are altered in people with chronic pain.
‚Ä¶
There is a direct correlation between improvement in one‚Äôs emotional well-being and their experience of pain (and vice versa). Chronic pain increases the risk of depression and anxiety, and depression and anxiety strongly predict the development of chronic pain. This association is seen in conditions like fibromyalgia and irritable bowel syndrome, where behavioural and psychological treatment strategies have shown benefit in reducing symptoms.‚Äù
.
Psychologists can help address‚Äî
Pain catastrophizing: This is when you magnify the negative effects of pain and focus on feelings of helplessness while ruminating about the presence of pain in your life. Negative thoughts and beliefs about pain often lead to worsened emotional and social functioning and a decreased response to medical interventions for pain.
Fear of pain: Concern or worry about an injury drives avoidant or protective behaviours. The anticipation of an increased sensation of pain may limit you from engaging in physical activity or attending social outings. Pain-avoidant behaviours can lead to physical deconditioning and further decreased quality of life.
Pain acceptance: This is a challenging, but highly effective technique focused on developing an accepting attitude towards the pain. It involves doing your best to nonjudgmentally acknowledge the presence of pain and minimise unhelpful thoughts and behaviours that won‚Äôt make pain better.
Trauma: The link between prior trauma and chronic pain is becoming better understood. Psychological therapies can address ongoing physical and emotional stress responses linked to traumatic experiences.

description:
[why you won‚Äôt regret talking to your teens about EVERYTHING] There is nothing too taboo to discuss and share.
.
‚ÄúAs soon as the kids were old enough, the moment they started asking questions, we talked about it. We told them at what age my husband and I tried alcohol, or smoked a cigarette. We talked about the mistakes we made and the consequences that followed. We talked about the lessons and the regrets.

Most importantly, we talked about the underlying reasons or traumas that led up to our poor decisions.
.
There is nothing we don‚Äôt discuss, no issue too taboo.‚Äù
.
Via @parentingteensandtweens @ https://parentingteensandtweens.com/why-you-wont-regret-talking-to-your-teens-about-everything/
.

May be an image of ‚Äécar, road and ‚Äétext that says '‚ÄéHome News Latest News HH News €îtst News Driver In Kovan Allegedly Assaulted For Not Giving Way, Road Users Urged Œ§Œø Be More Courteous‚Äé'‚Äé‚Äé.
description:
[higher instances of Road RAGE?] Man Allegedly Punches Fellow Driver In Kovan For Not Giving Way ‚Äî Even as we try our best to be courteous in our everyday lives, certain interactions like driving dilemmas can bring out the worst in us. On Saturday (15 Jan), road rage got the best of a man in Kovan who allegedly punched another driver he was unhappy with. However, what if there‚Äôs a deeper issue in our midst?
.
It‚Äôs been 2 years since COVID hit us‚Ä¶ We have had to tolerate and deal with harsh realities, increasing stress and frustrations in all walks of life. At the tail end of the 2021, when we think things are settling, we re-enter into the new year as though the emotional trauma was already resolved. OF COURSE NOT‚Ä¶ it is highly likely we do not let go of these emotional challenges as we re-engage with sending our children to school in the mornings, not giving way because we‚Äôve [not] had our way, and for many of us, coping with adjusting to new contexts like school and return to work fully vaxxed in 2022 (lest we lose our jobs) are just examples of the tip of the iceberg.
.
Psychologically speaking, these instances cause us to ‚Äòregress‚Äô [to psychologically become immature/childlike] and ‚Äòsublimate‚Äô [to convert disowned feelings into more socially acceptable means as justifiably unleashed on the road and other motorists]. There, you have road rage. Of course, we get to see other instances of rage being vented into other coping forms and styles but until we get a hang of our emotional concerns, individuals would be none the wiser. You‚Äôve heard it first from TPP, as your needs are always kept in mind.
.
Full article via @mustsharenews @ https://mustsharenews.com/kovan-driver-assault/
.

May be an image of text that says 'How To Take Care of Yourself If The Holidays Trigger Your C-PTSD'.
description:
[How To Take Care Of Yourself If The Holidays Trigger Your C-PTSD] This is the season when so many of us talk a lot about holiday stress ‚Äî the ramped up social calendars, the added commitments and chores and the burden of airports and delayed flights. And yes, all of these things are overwhelming. 
.
But what we don‚Äôt often hear about is how triggering the holiday season can be, specifically if you live with complex post-traumatic stress disorder (C-PTSD) or come from a relational trauma background. Many people have strained, estranged or just plain painful relationships with their family of origin and/or their partner‚Äôs family of origin, which can make the holidays difficult.
.
It‚Äôs not uncommon in these situations for folks to spend the entire calendar year dreading the winter holidays. The last six weeks of the year can feel especially triggering for C-PTSD symptoms.
.
If this is you and you dread the holidays, or if you know that the holiday season might trigger your C-PTSD symptoms, bear in mind these very important self-care points that could help you this holiday season.
.
Full article @themightysite https://themighty.com/2020/12/how-to-take-care-of-yourself-if-the-holidays-trigger-your-c-ptsd/
.

[ahead of the holiday season] Dear friends, colleagues and partners in our cherished community, you know we love people and you know we have a heart for our collective experiences. Every year we try to keep your needs in mind, and that includes the individuals who are hurting and do not relate to the holiday cheer at all.
.
The year-end season can be associated with loss, trauma, and severe emotional pain, which can remind of how uncomfortable and frequently inconsolable it can be. Hence, there is no amount of sugar-coating or positivity bullsh*t that can cover up the reality of life. Besides, the past two years has been absolutely dismal although we've made it this far!
.
HOLD ON! Before this might sound like a weird Christmas greeting that's gone nightmarishly wrong, we encourage you all to stay close to your loved ones, or at least stay safe in your most secure space. Cuddle up, watch some TV, or go occupy yourself with your favourite past time for a good moment [you know best]. If your TPP therapist goes on break, it doesn't mean that you're no longer thought of - On the contrary, you're always kept in mind and that also means understanding how you may feel when they are not present for the time being.
.
So, do keep well, and we wish you a peaceful and secure year's end. - Love, TPP. xoxo
.

[ Catch-up Post: The Community Rehab Family ]

Was glad to have been a part of the twin celebration for the 50th and 25th anniversaries of the Volunteer Probation Officer (VPO) and Community Service (CS) schemes before I flew for Bahrain! üéâ

During the event, I spoke to ‚ÄòEmily‚Äô (not her real name), a probationer who shared her community service experience with the Marsiling Youth Network (YN), and how it helped her find her footing in the community. Emily once faced rejection for her past mistakes. Through her community service placement with the YN, she slowly regained her confidence, as her involvement affirmed her potential and she was given opportunities to build on her strengths. üí™üèºüí™üèº

Such stories reflect the transformative power that our community partners have in nurturing our youths. We are grateful to our VPOs and CS agencies, for your strong partnership with MSF Singapore (@msfcares) in supporting our probationers in community rehabilitation! ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

The journey is not always easy, but your perseverance, patience and passion have been most inspiring and heart-warming! Let‚Äôs all continue to build a village of care and support to guide and mentor them so they can press on and realise their true potential. üëçüèªüëçüèª

If you have 5mins, watch this video for an #unfiltered sharing by our probationers, VPOs, and friends from our CS agencies.

#EveryYouthHasPotential #SGYouth #SGUnited #YouthVoices #SingaporeTogether #EricCares

May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Psychology Today MINDFULNESS The Limits of Mindfulness For the greatest benift understand the risks clearly.'.
description:
[the LIMITS of Mindfulness] Take it from us: For the greatest benefit understand the risks clearly. So, don‚Äôt just ride the mindfulness trend, it‚Äôs just one aspect of psychological functioning. Furthermore, it‚Äôs an entirely different approach toward living that if just treated as an intervention, we might pay for it dearly with certain psychological consequences.
.
The ability to observe one‚Äôs emotions is also touted as a major benefit of mindfulness, and for many of us, this is indeed true. Yet can it go too far? Can we become too distanced from our experience? Indeed we can. Britton (2019) reviews multiple studies showing connections between meditation training and blunted emotionality and even dissociation for some participants.
.
Sometimes mindfulness practices are taught to help us overcome avoidance, as a way of ‚Äúbeing with‚Äù that which is difficult. Again, much of the time this can offer great benefit. However, the reality is that some people don‚Äôt struggle as much with avoidance but instead become preoccupied with their troubles. For such individuals, the instruction to stay with a challenging experience may not be beneficial and could even be counterproductive.
.
There tends to be a ‚Äúmore is better‚Äù attitude among mindfulness practitioners, where the answer to whatever ails you can easily become ‚Äúpractice more mindfulness.‚Äù Britton (2019) reminds us of the importance of paying attention to the duration of practice and where there might be diminishing returns or even harmful effects. For instance, she reviews research suggesting that meditation may help sleep only up to a certain amount, after which it may actually make sleep more difficult.
.

May be an image of one or more people, people standing and text that says 'cna Top Stories Latest News Discover Singapore A Commentary: Allowing two adults to divorce in mutual agreement is hardly radical or revolutionary No-fault divorce is a welcome change amid changing ideas of marriage and gender roles, says SUSS sociologist Hu Shu.'.
description:
[TOWARDS AN EGALITARIAN PARTNERSHIP] As modern ideals of love, marriage and individual fulfillment became widely accepted, couples typically enter a marriage with the expectation that it will bring happiness, emotional satisfaction, and personal growth.
.
With changing gender roles resulting from rising educational attainment and female labour force participation, women also increasingly expect an egalitarian partnership in financial contribution, emotional engagement, and household labour.
.
When a marriage ceases to satisfy these needs and expectations or even becomes harmful to one‚Äôs physical and mental health, divorce becomes rational and necessary.
.
No-fault divorce will not encourage divorce or discourage marriage, but it will make the divorce process less acrimonious for those who are already determined to end a counterproductive marriage.
.
If divorcing couples could part on more amicable terms, it would help them and their children to adapt and move on in life more quickly.
.
It benefits no one to drag out an unhappy marriage in a lengthy and agonising process of divorce.
.
Via @channelnewsasia @cnainsider @cnalifestyle
.

Family violence comes in many forms such as emotional and psychological abuse, sexual abuse and neglect. Some are so subtle that the victims themselves may not realize that they are in one. But the truth is, family violence is real, there are indeed people suffering in silence, and we need to start acknowledging and fighting against it. 

I‚Äôve partnered up with the Ministry of Social and Family Development to raise awareness for the Break The Silence campaign, and encourage bystanders to lend a helping hand and encourage victims to seek help if they know of anyone suffering from family violence. 

If you‚Äôre going through family violence, swipe right to find out more on how you can discreetly use the Signal for Help, and how you can respond when you spot others performing the signal. 

#BreaktheSilence 
#SignalforHelp 
#FamilyViolence

description:
It's time to #BreaktheSilence. Home is supposed to be a safe place for us, but that is not always the case. Family violence is a topic that is not talked about enough. It comes in many forms such as physical abuse, emotional and psychological abuse, sexual abuse, financial abuse and neglect. This is a message to anyone who is experiencing family violence - please don't hesitate to help others AND seek help. Learn about the Signal for Help on my IGS now. This is a simple one-handed gesture to discreetly communicate that you are at risk. If you see someone using this signal, please respond by:

‚úî Asking general ‚Äúyes‚Äù or ‚Äúno‚Äù questions to reduce risk and make it easier for them to respond 
‚úî Don‚Äôt respond immediately, whether physical or online 
‚úî Only reaching out by using another form of communication (text, Whatsapp, social media, email etc) 

Let's do this together. The more we speak in unity, the louder our voices are heard. Visit my IGS for more information. üíï 

#BreaktheSilence #StopFamilyViolence #SignalforHelp

[ Helping Our Rough Sleeping Friends ]

Last weekend, I visited the good people (Pastor Reuben, Asst. Pastor Shannon & team) at Faith Methodist Church, Singapore. Visited the Safe, Sound Sleeping Place (S3P) that they‚Äôd set up within the church compounds and spoke with 3 rough sleepers who were seeking refuge in the S3P. 

The issue of rough sleeping is close to my heart. I read the commentary by Dr Harry Tan and team on homelessness on 16 Nov, titled ‚ÄúHelping the homeless beyond putting a roof over their heads‚Äù and I am truly thankful for the partnerships we‚Äôd formed in the Partners Engaging and Empowering Rough Sleepers (PEERS) Network.

Other than operating S3Ps, our PEERS partners go on regular night walks to befriend our rough sleeping friends. I join them and our MSF colleagues on these night walks and I‚Äôm grateful for the community of support we‚Äôd built up since the Network was formed.

I also shared my views and MSF Singapore's approach toward rough sleeping in the ST Forum page today. We all can play a part in helping our rough sleeping friends. If you come across rough sleepers who may need support or shelter, please call the ComCare Hotline at 1800-222-0000 or email the PEERS Office at msf_peersoffice@msf.gov.sg.

You can read the commentary here: https://www.straitstimes.com/opinion/helping-the-homeless-beyond-putting-a-roof-over-their-heads, 

And my forum letter here: https://www.straitstimes.com/opinion/forum/forum-everyone-can-play-a-part-to-support-rough-sleepers

TL;DR ‚Äì We all can help our rough sleeping friends! ‚ù§Ô∏è

#EricCares #CaringNInclusive #RoughSleeping #Homelessness #PEERS #PEERSNetwork #MSFCares

If you‚Äôve met my husband in person, you‚Äôll understand how my baby is still alive under my care. I‚Äôm grateful that God has blessed Ethan with such a hands-on father because life will be terribly challenging otherwise. 

Take bathing @howisethan for example, the only reason why he is clean is because his father has been showering him since the day he came home. The first few times were uncomfortable but eventually bathing became their father and son bonding time. Whew!

Gone are the days when dads just play with their kids and leave the hard part to the moms! It‚Äôs 2021 and so glad to see a lot of dads equally caring for their kids from feeding them milk and solids, changing their diapers to washing their clothes. The only things they probably can‚Äôt do is latching and giving birth but that‚Äôs not really within their control. 

So to my husband @neoquadra, thank you for loving and annoying (see reel for reference) your son. Keep it up and to all the dads out there, know what we appreciate you and all that you do for the family! 

To borrow a quote, ‚ÄúAny man can be a father, but it takes someone special to a dad.‚Äù

Oh did you see my boy‚Äôs annoyed face? üòÇ

#fatherandson #fatherhood #sgparents #sgdad #sgbaby

May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'SL MAMAHOOD PARENTING ADVICE FOR ALL SINGAPORE PARENTS From the Expert, Health & Wellness, Highlights@MSG, Kids Development, Kids Health November 12, 2021 Ms Andrea Chong, A Psychologist Helps Us To Understand Better About A Child's Psychology'.
description:
[Mamahood: Understanding your child‚Äôs psychology] Mamahood held an exclusive interview with expert, Ms. Andrea Chong, a Psychologist with The Psychology Practice, who will help us understand more about children‚Äôs psychology, and how it can help to elevate our parenting methods.
.
Q8. When and why should I bring my child to see a psychologist? What are the factors that I should look for to bring my child to a psychologist before it is too late?
.
Andrea: One key area of concern would be significant changes to their daily functioning or behaviour such as prolonged changes in their mood where they can be more withdrawn or irritable and when they are showing expressions of self-harm or suicidal ideation. Trust your parental instincts and do note that it is never too late to attend to a child and to offer them support.
‚Ä¶
Q10. If I need to bring my child to a therapist, how can I explain this to him?
.
Andrea: Depending on the age of the child, gently point out your concerns about their mental health and ask if they might like to speak to someone who can help. You may provide more information about what a psychologist or therapist does.
.
One way would be to explain that when our bodies are not well. For example, when we display cold/flu symptoms, we see a doctor to help us feel better ‚Äì hence it would be the same when our mind/heart is not well. When we feel sad, anxious or angry a lot, therefore we see a psychologist or therapist to help us feel better. If the child is resistant to the idea, do not coerce them but continue offering them support while also encouraging them to get help.
.
Read the full interview @ https://story.mamahood.com.sg/understand-childs-psychology/
.

[how has the pandemic affected those with SPECIAL NEEDS?] What impact does the pandemic have on particular sub-populations in our context? Let's learn more. In our last post, we focused on increased levels of suicide, as a backdrop to the pandemic experienced in Singapore. To appreciate how it can bring our fellow countrymen to their knees, we draw a lens onto those with special needs. But first, we need to understand why these individuals with special needs have these struggles, then we can assist them.
.
Here are some tips to approach the conversation:
(1) Normalise what they are feeling and help them identify their emotions.
(2) Don't overload them with information, as it can be overwhelming.
(3) Remind them that there is always people around to support them.
(4) Link them up with the relevant professionals.
.
If you found this helpful, do share our message and images around should they benefit someone level up on their mental health literacy.
.
üñº by Naomi
.

description:
[a taboo topic] What do you know about Eating Disorders and its psychological treatment? ‚Äî In Singapore, there is high body dissatisfaction among youths which is a known risk factor for Eating Disorders (ED). For instance, a survey found that 85% of participants aged 18 to 24 were dissatisfied with their body (Baker, 2018). From 2016 to 2020, there was an average of 300 patients per year who received treatment for various eating disorders from Singaporean public hospitals, with a median patient age of 21 years old (Khan, 2021). Singapore General Hospital (SGH), which is one of the few hospitals in Singapore with a multidisciplinary and specialised team for treating EDs, also sees patients who usually present symptoms between 17 to 22 years old (Baker, 2018).
.
Despite an increase in global prevalence of Eating Disorders, there is little conversation and awareness surrounding this issue, especially among peers of the tertiary age group. In collaboration with @nus_singapore students, TPP Clinical Psychologist Ms. Lynette Tan was interviewed for her professional views. This ebook will help raise awareness about ED and normalise discussions about mental wellness, body image, and developing a healthy relationship with food and exercise.
.
Access the E-book now to learn more! Link via https://sway.office.com/y25CEzUHTxM3EEUO
.

[mental health affects all ages, including the elderly] Suicide cases in Singapore highest in 8 years amid COVID-19 pandemic. As reported on @channelnewsasia (8 Jul 2021), "Singapore reported 452 suicides last year, the nation's highest count since 2012, amid the isolation and psychological distress brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic. Last year's case count was a 13 per cent increase from the 400 cases recorded in 2019, according to data released by the Samaritans of Singapore (SOS) on Thursday (Jul 8).
.
The increase was observed across all age groups but in particular the elderly, which recorded the highest number of suicides since 1991. Among people aged 60 and above, a total of 154 took their own lives. This was a 26 per cent increase from 2019." Link to article here: https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/suicide-highest-record-elderly-mental-health-isolation-covid-19-1984716
.
It's clear that the mental health of our elderly is under fire! So, let's understand how they are affected, and what we can do as a nation to support the mental health needs of our seniors.
.
If you found this helpful, do share our message and images around should they benefit someone level up on their mental health literacy.
.
üñº by Naomi
.

May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Psychology Today Why Do Narcissistic Employees Get Promoted Fast? Research identifies mechanisms underlying narcissists' promotability at work.'.
description:
[why do narcissistic employees get promoted fast?] Research identifies mechanisms underlying narcissists‚Äô promotability at work. You might find this to be quite an illuminating article. We suggest this article to leaders and Human Resources of your organisation, as a psychological way of understanding employee dynamics. Perhaps an organisational psychologist might be useful as a consideration for your business.
.
Here‚Äôs some highlights:
‚Ä¢ People high in narcissism seem to have considerable success in many domains in life, including at work‚Äîfor example, they get promoted fast.
‚Ä¢ Narcissistic employees‚Äô promotability may be due to their impression management skills and, especially, their displays of power.
‚Ä¢ Using the same techniques narcissists employ, such as displaying more power, may help non-narcissistic employees get the promotions they deserve.
.
‚ÄúIn general, making promotability assessments is more difficult than many other types of assessments (e.g., performance review). Why? Because promotability assessments are based less on concrete information regarding an employee‚Äôs success on a particular project and more on intangible qualities, like cues of future potential. These cues, of course, include displays of power, something narcissists tend to know how to do very well.‚Äù
.
Via @psych_today
.

[how does childhood emotional injustice affect your adult behaviour?] Ever wondered why psychologists keep harping on what happened to you in your earlier days? You might be surprised at what you learn! ü§î
.
We hark back to the earlier days of TPP where we continue to help others cultivate psychological thinking, which is such an important capacity of ours in daily functioning.
.
Let‚Äôs stoke our thinking today, considering some shared behaviours of those who are victims of childhood emotional injustice: 
(1) Low self-esteem
(2) Distrust of others
(3) Easily worried and overwhelmed
(4) 'Dangerous' coping behaviours
.
If you found this helpful, do share our message and images around should they benefit someone level up on their mental health literacy.

[Feeling lost with the many psychological therapies available?] What are the types of psychological therapies available? We hark back to the earlier days of TPP where we continue to help others cultivate psychological thinking, which is such an important capacity of ours in daily functioning. Let‚Äôs stoke our thinking today, considering what needs to be considered in this potentially confusing process.
.
There is NO one size fits all - It is good to start by asking yourself what you are seeking in therapy! Your NEEDS and GOALS can be explored, and further developed with your therapist.
.
Some needs may require a different focus and approach, especially since one's struggles can be acute or longstanding, and differ in terms of its severity. Therefore, two evidence-based forms of effective therapies are suggested here as a useful way to jumpstart your search. Remember, if you're in doubt, always consult a credible source who can point you in the right direction.
.
If you found this helpful, do share our message and images around should they benefit someone level up on their mental health literacy.
.
üñº by Naomi
.

[how do you teach your child to say sorry?] Or, how do you apologise to your child? ü§≠
‚Äî Even if it‚Äôs difficult, admit you were wrong and share only your remorse.
.
‚ÄúWe tell children, ‚ÄòGo apologise to your brother,‚Äô but they can learn more by experiencing you apologising to them,‚Äù says Jeremy Ruckstaetter, a professor of counseling at Covenant Theological Seminary in St. Louis, Mo. When Ruckstaetter started researching apologies in graduate school, he found perplexingly few studies focusing on apologies from parents to children. For his doctoral dissertation, he surveyed 327 parents and found that those who regularly apologised to their children reported stronger attachment bonds.
.
Yes, parents need to display a remorse and take charge of their own responses. When you show that your apology is unconditional (meaning that you don‚Äôt make them pay in your next sentence), they learn from your display and know that it‚Äôs possible to take that stance. This teaches them about humility, pride and that apologies can mend relational problems and increase intimacy! Read on to learn more.
.

[what do you know about Psychiatric Diagnosis with the DSM?] If you know very little about psychiatric diagnosis, this clip promises to be an eye opener and serves as a way to stimulate understanding of its relationship to psychological therapy. Watch this interview with Dr. Greg Murray, Professor in Psychological Sciences at Swinburne University, Australia. He is interviewed about what a psychiatric diagnosis means, and what it doesn‚Äôt mean. We hark back to the earlier days of TPP where we continue to help others cultivate psychological thinking, which is such an important capacity of ours in daily functioning. Let‚Äôs stoke our thinking today.
.
Dr. Murray is also a practicing clinical psychologist, involved nationally with the training and accreditation of clinical psychologists. His major research interest is the chronobiology of mood, especially the relationship between sleep, circadian function, and positive mood states, and he has over 100 publications in this area. The majority of his work follows a collaborative and multi-disciplinary framework. Greg is a co-author on the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists‚Äô Mood Disorder Guidelines, and wrote the Australian Psychological Society‚Äôs guidelines for psychological treatment of bipolar disorder. He is currently leading a 4-year project to develop and test a new online intervention (ORBIT) for people who have had a large number of episodes of bipolar disorder.
.

[‚ÄòFighting the Fright‚Äô this Halloween üéÉ weekend!] When phobias take over our lives, they can affect our well-being. Understanding the psychology of fear can go a long way to tackling the problem. This article was published Oct 2020 - Jan 2021, following an interview with the Trauma Services team at the Institute of Mental Health, Singapore. Read on to learn more about our phobias, anxieties and avoidant responses.
.
‚ÄúPeople with phobias often cope by avoiding the feared object or situation as far as possible and hardly seek help. As a result, the avoidance reinforces the fear and the phobia tends to persist.‚Äù - Ms Andrea Chong, now resident TPP Psychodynamic Psychotherapist speaks.
.

According to a joint press release by @msfcares and @mhasingapore, family violence has a negative effect on its survivors and those who witnessed the violence. Maltreated children and youth offenders who witnessed family violence are more likely to develop emotional and behavioural problems. 

In September, our staff organised an internal training on Introduction to Managing Family Violence. The training touched on the creation of safe space, theories on family violence, intervention/application of theories and crafting of a safety plan.

TW // ABUSE

EP 33: When affections turn into abuse (with Zionette Esther)

Zionette Esther's story of abuse is an important one to tell. She shares about how she first met her ex-husband, how they fell in love and out of it. It all started when her honeymoon turned into a "horror-moon" and due to a series of events, the verbal outbursts gradually led to physical violence. Over time, she learnt to open up to her family and friends about her situation and with their help, managed to escape her narcissistic ex-husband, leaving him for good. We hope that Zionette's story can help those who are facing similar situations to have the courage to do what is right by them. 

If you are reading this and feel like you can relate to it and you need someone to talk to, do not hesitate to drop us a DM. ‚ù§

[worried about your mental health?] What should you look out for in general that could be suggesting you need some assistance or support? Maybe this reminder can help. We hark back to the earlier days of TPP where we continue to help others cultivate psychological thinking, which is such an important capacity of ours in daily functioning. Following yesterday‚Äôs post that ignited some interesting responses and discussion on LinkedIn, we think these are the pertinent issues that need to be fleshed out ‚Äî to combat stigma and a lack of mental health literacy, we need to keep asking questions. So, let‚Äôs stoke our thinking today. Hear us out!
.
What are your personal Warning Signs that could signal to you that you are going through some mental health concerns? What underlies your stress could encompass a whole range of issues like (and not limited to):
‚Ä¢ Changes in personal routine
‚Ä¢ Social withdrawal
‚Ä¢ A drop in your daily functioning
‚Ä¢ Mental/cognitive issues
.
Whether a result of COVID, or pre-existing issues that have emerged and intensified, they are all valid concerns. Look up your preferred mental health professional for some advice on whether you need to be concerned or start by checking in with a trusted person who could tell you that you‚Äôve just been hanging on. Take charge of your own personal needs today.
.
What can you do for YOURSELF today? If you found this helpful, do share our message and images around should they benefit someone level up on their mental health literacy.
.
üñº by Naomi
.

description:
[psychological therapy is NOT a fad] Gen Y Speaks: Feeling lost, I sought psychological help. I am learning much about myself and my past.
.
I was advised to seek professional help to understand myself better as a therapist would be able to ask the right questions and guide me in finding my true self.
.
I was informed that therapy is not a quick solution. In fact, it will take at least three months to get somewhere and can take up to a few years to heal all those years of trauma.
.
Through therapy, I now understand that it was because deep down inside me, I felt that no one ever stood up for me so I feel the need to stand up for the weak and unfairly treated.
.
Read the full article via @todayonline @ https://www.todayonline.com/gen-y-speaks/gen-y-speaks-feeling-lost-i-sought-psychological-help-i-am-learning-much-about-myself
.

description:
[CNA938Live Q&A] Parental Concerns: Lead-up to Primary School Leaving Exams
.
Listen in on @channelnewsasia Q&A as Lance Alexander and Melanie Oliveiro discuss the challenges of preparing for the Primary School Leaving Examinations (PSLE) for both students and their parents during the COVID-19 pandemic. Join guest experts, Dr. Shawn Ee, TPP Clinical Psychologist & Psychoanalytic Psychotherapist, Dir The Psychology Practice, and Dr. Petrina Wong, Consultant Paediatrician, SOG Clinic for Children, Gleneagles Hospital, as they make sense of the underlying issues.
.
Highlights:
‚Ä¢ What should parents be mindful of when it comes to the stresses and experience of children during exams?
‚Ä¢ What should parents do to ease their children‚Äôs and their own anxiety?
‚Ä¢ What are signs that your child is under too much stress and suffering from anxiety?
‚Ä¢ What are some parental behaviours that may place unintended stress on children ahead of exams?
.
Other issues raised included: Engaging children physically and mentally, managing one's worries, recognising the telltale signs of stress, use of screen-time, Home-Based Learning woes, mindfulness meditation, helpful/unhelpful things said to kids, and the value and appropriate use of tuition.
.
Full interview available @ https://youtu.be/P81qRRtJ8uc
.

May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'WHAT IS SOCIAL CONNECTION? The subjective experience of feeling close to and sense ofbes with others. THE BENEFITS OF HIGH SOCIAL CONNECTION: il ]50% 50% increased chance of longevity stronger gene expression for immunity (research by Steve Cole, UCLA) Ëä± lower rates fanxiety and depression ‡Æ® higher self-esteem and empathy better emotion regulation skills Social connection creates a positive feedback loop of social, emotional, and physical well being.'.
description:
[connect to thrive!] Connectedness & Health: The Science of Social Connection ‚Äî Social connection improves physical health and mental and emotional well-being.
.
We all think we know how to take good are of ourselves: eat your veggies, work out and try to get enough sleep. But how many of us know that social connection is just as critical?
.
One landmark study showed that lack of social connection is a greater detriment to health than obesity, smoking and high blood pressure.
.
On the other hand, strong social connection:
‚Ä¢ leads to a 50% increased chance of longevity
‚Ä¢ strengthens your immune system(research by Steve Cole shows that genes impacted by loneliness also code for immune function and inflammation)
‚Ä¢ helps you recover from disease faster
‚Ä¢ may even lengthen your life!
.
People who feel more connected to others have lower levels of anxiety and depression. Moreover, studies show they also have higher self-esteem, greater empathy for others, are more trusting and cooperative and, as a consequence, others are more open to trusting and cooperating with them. In other words, social connectedness generates a positive feedback loop of social, emotional and physical well-being.
.
Unfotunately, the opposite is also true for those who lack social connectedness. Low levels of social connection are associated with declines in physical and psychological health as well as a higher likelihood for antisocial behavior that leads to further isolation. Learn more, look us up!
.

May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'S'pore counsellors face burnout as more people seek therapy amid Covid-19 pandemic'.
description:
[just in] Counsellors in Singapore are facing burnout and high demand amid the Covid-19 pandemic as more individuals seek therapy to cope with mental health concerns and stress related to employment and family relationships ‚Äî Oh, you don‚Äôt say! That‚Äôs about the same ratio of an influx of clients being seen at our practice!
.
What do you reckon? More issues or more awareness? Either way, it‚Äôs good news people are beginning to care about their own backyard and feel their personal issues are legitimate. [HOWEVER] If you‚Äôre a mental health professional, seek help, manage your caseload, get therapy, do something. Why? Strap in for the long-term, because the responsibility of self-care falls on (you guessed it!) yourSELF, and not on your organisation. The way things are going, we can only expect more individuals to come forward for help, which means more burnout and less stability for the provision of treatment. Dear employers, do cut your staff some slack, it‚Äôs already tough as it is as a mental health worker. They need all the support they can get.
.
Via @straits_times @ S'pore counsellors face burnout as more people seek therapy amid Covid-19 pandemic https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/spore-counsellors-face-burnout-as-more-people-seek-therapy-amid-covid-19-pandemic
.

description:
[grim and disturbing news] Did you know that sexual offending behaviour is preceded and maintained by psychological dynamics and issues? Whether you have a simple idea of individuals preying on vulnerable populations, to more complex ideas like the abuse of power and emotional blackmail, trust can easily be eroded and not to mention victims who fall foul to these crimes always end up dealing with sexual and psychological trauma for the rest of their lives. However, the ugly truth is that according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), ‚ÄòPaedophilia‚Äô or individuals with paedophilic tendencies, NEVER go into remission ‚Äî It is an insidious and dangerous aspect of an individual‚Äôs psychological structure that requires ongoing management and accountability apart from legal recourse and punishment.
.
We need a growing psychological awareness of disturbing issues in our community. Remember, according to the research, many of these sexual offences occur in the family home. If you‚Äôre concerned with your own situation and have feared making a report, it may be time to alert the necessary authorities. Start by telling someone safe so you don‚Äôt remain silent. Please do not underestimate the psychological consequences of these acts.
.
New articles via @todayonline
.

May be a cartoon of text that says 'PAST TRAUMA BAD PANDEMIC PAST STRESS TRAUMA WS PANDEMI√á PAST STRESS TRAUMA think you're overreacting. MINOR INCONVENIENCE theAwkwardyeti.com'.
description:
[trauma‚Äôs unseen stressors] It‚Äôs always easy to make light of one‚Äôs experiences because we don‚Äôt always get to see the obvious or subtle factors that underlie the trauma response. That‚Äôs because traumatised individuals psychologically defend themselves in their own personally protective ways, and they do it well! That‚Äôs why most of the time, we don‚Äôt get to see the most painful parts of one‚Äôs overreactions and run the risk of rejecting or trivialising their surface responses ‚Äî well, at least not until they break down and display overt difficulties, that it may be a tad late down the line. So, always check in with those close to you, no matter how it seems like they may be okay. Besides, they can always say ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm fine‚Äù, then in that case, we can learn to respect their say and display an appreciation of their right to when they are ready. A big part of trauma treatment is being able to allow the person the right to regain some loss of control and being able to make sense of their own experiences in their own time. We get you.
.
üñº credits: @theawkwardyeti
.

description:
Are you an employer or a key position holder in your company who designs HR policies?

Or are you a breastfeeding mother who needs some assistance to help your company provide more breastfeeding-friendly policies?

BMSG is happy to announce our support for workplaces through our Breastfeeding Support Kit for Employers!

This kit consists of a variety of resources and tools for employers and nursing mothers, including a special guidebook just for employers on all matters breastfeeding.

Our kit will help you think about the different aspects of how breastfeeding can be supported at the workplace: from design breastfeeding-friendly HR policies, setting up a workable and conducive nursing room for employees to understanding how other companies have helped their breastfeeding employees. 

This Breastfeeding Support Kit for Employers is absolutely FREE!

As production is currently on the way, we expect the kits to be ready by October this year.

Meanwhile, you can submit a name for any company or orgnanisation who will benefit from this Kit and we will send them over personally at no additional costs.

Sign up on the link in our bio or click here: bit.ly/empsupportkit

description:
[Just in: This is for you parents!] ‚ÄúMy grades are fine, but I'm not‚Äù ‚Äî What young people wish adults knew about their mental health challenges
.
The increasing openness towards discussing youth mental health and emotions may be hard for parents to relate to, since they did not grow up in the same context and use of particular ways of describing one‚Äôs concerns.
.
As such, being curious and empathising with their teen‚Äôs feelings and experiences will help parents better support their child‚Äôs transition to adulthood. Providing a listening ear is better than jumping in with advice, although professional help should be sought when necessary.
.
Five things to note:
‚Ä¢ Having good grades does not mean I am okay
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt glamorise or downplay mental illness
‚Ä¢ Give me time to recover
‚Ä¢ It is hard to quit social media when Instagram is your diary
‚Ä¢ Believe me when I say I am in pain
.
Full article via @straits_times @ https://www.straitstimes.com/life/my-grades-are-fine-but-im-not
.

[Supporting vulnerable residents @ NSL]

Even though we have reduced face to face meetings over the last few weeks, the GRLs and I have been working hard to connect with agencies and VWOs so that we can better render help to the vulnerable in our community. We had very fruitful discussions and agreed on further collaboration opportunities.

Today, we met Blossom Seeds, a not-for-profit organization that supports our seniors in NSL.  One of the more popular services has been the Medical Escort & Transport services that they provide to our residents.  I am delighted that their Chairman Mr Aw and CEO Siew Chin have reaffirmed that commitment strengthen their partnership with NSL. We also agreed to support their recruitment for volunteers to support our neighbourhood so that we can expand the services.

Recently, we also meet with Yishun Social Service Office (SSO) team led by Mdm Salmiah.  The team briefed us on the Support schemes available and also clarified our questions.  We also agreed to help reach out to residents who need urgent help yet have not provided the full information for financial assistance.

With thanks to the Blossom Seeds team and SSO team for the help given to the vulnerable in our community. I am sure our partnership with strengthen further for the benefit of residents. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

(1st photo: with Blossom Seeds team; 2nd photo: with SSO team)

#kithandkinlc #estateplanninglawyer

Last week, we addressed burnout in adults at the workplace. Do you think burnout applies to students in schools too?

Students at the primary school level are reporting symptoms of anxiety and stress related to school, where extreme cases have driven them to suicide. Youths often face long days at school, hours of homework, and are then pushed by parents to have private tuition. This creates an impact on mental wellbeing, with rising numbers seeking psychiatric help as they struggle to cope with the relentless pressure for academic excellence.

Statistics by the Samaritans of Singapore show that suicide is the leading cause of death for those aged 10 to 29 with 452 lives lost to suicide in 2020 alone. This includes a 37.5 per cent increase from 2019 for the age group of 10 to 19. Education Minister, Mr Chan Chun Sing, has also acknowledged that the overall increase in suicides in young people this year have been due to the Covid-19 pandemic aggravating existing stressors. This pushes the notion of student welfare and mental wellbeing to be of utmost importance.

If you need help, please reach out to @samaritansofsingapore, @samhsingapore, Institute of Mental Health Singapore, @ncss.sg and @beyondthelabelsg.

#SOM2021 #SoundofMindSG

description:
[feature article on Time magazine] A New Documentary Tells the Harrowing History of Conversion Therapy ‚Äî Learning indeed can occur outside of the classroom! Not for anything political or anti-religion, but for mental health and psychological well-being.
.
Although it is now recognised as dangerous pseudoscience by the medical establishment, and banned in 20 U.S. states, conversion therapy remains endemic in many conservative, religious communities‚Äîand as ‚ÄòPray Away‚Äô documents, is grounding a new generation of believers in its rhetoric as part of larger culture wars being waged over gay and trans rights. But many of the movement‚Äôs early leaders and figureheads have since recanted [‚Äòroti prata‚Äô-ed]; in many cases coming out (or back out) as gay and speaking out about the harm they experienced‚Äîand that they caused.
.
When you believe you‚Äôre doing the right thing, and you‚Äôre doing it also in the name of religion, it can put you into a deep place of denial. This is the fuel of what continues conversion therapy and the movement more generally into the present day, despite the undeniable evidence that it doesn‚Äôt work‚Äîand that it causes trauma.
.
Read the full article via @time @ https://time.com/6088170/pray-away-documentary/
.

May be an image of person, child and text that says 'A cna CNA Insider 'With school counsellors, it's really hit-or- miss': Behind the challenge of safeguarding student mental health As recent events throw a spotlight on the mental health of Singapore's youth, questions have been raised on how equipped schools are to help this generation. Students, teachers and counsellors tell CNA Insider the problems, conflicts and the way forward.'.
description:
[Get the Scoop! On CNA Insider] ‚ÄòWith school counsellors, it‚Äôs really hit-or-miss‚Äô: Behind the challenge of safeguarding student mental health ‚Äî There is a disparity in student experiences when it comes to school counselling!
.
As recent events throw a spotlight on the mental health of Singapore‚Äôs youth, questions have been raised on how equipped schools are to help this generation. Students, teachers and counsellors tell CNA Insider the problems, conflicts and the way forward.
.
While a handful of people shared positive experiences, there were common complaints that the counsellors belittled the students‚Äô problems by making comparisons with others, or that the counsellors would ‚Äúsnitch‚Äù on them to their teachers or parents.
.
For some, students go to school counsellors because they need an escape from academics. But when they go to the school counsellor, they end up talking more about academics. It‚Äôs kind of counter-intuitive.
.
Whilst some can overlook the snitching and need a listening ear, ‚ÄúIt feels like a very shameful thing, and I guess being in a school environment, people gossip. I was really scared people would see me going to the counsellor and think something‚Äôs wrong with me,‚Äù a student said.
.
Learn more about the real challenges of school counselling and what it entails via @cnainsider @ https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/cnainsider/school-counselling-challenge-safeguard-student-mental-health-15350998
.

description:
[had to breakup due to the pandemic?] Heartbreak season: More couples are calling it quits amid challenges wrought by the pandemic ‚Äî ‚Äúthe course of true love never did run smooth‚Äù üò© ‚Äî ever wondered why the story of R+J was so tragic/traumatic?‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs because the idea of the separation was unresolved and out of one‚Äôs control.
.
Travel restrictions due to closed borders brought about by Covid-19 also led to the demise of some long-distance relationships. Whilst it is true that a lack of physical contact and quality time spent with each other bears some importance to the development of romantic relationships, maybe it is a good time to evaluate what is it that we look out for that keeps us sufficiently maintained in (or out of) our relationships. This includes our relational insecurities.
.
Full article via @straits_times @ https://www.straitstimes.com/life/heartbreak-season-more-couples-are-calling-it-quits-amid-challenges-wrought-by-the-pandemic
.

May be an image of 3 people, people standing and text that says 'THESTRAITSTIMES Students prefer their teachers to counsellors for mental health support PRIME Ëµ∞Ëøá‰∏ç Ë¶ÅÂæóËøáÔºÅ *---** Smn 350 TM'.
description:
[are teacher-counsellors the solution?] The verdict is out! Students prefer their teachers to counsellors for mental health support but ‚Äòteacher-counsellors‚Äô is NOT a good idea. Why do we say that? Let‚Äôs see.
.
The role of a teacher and the role of a counsellor are unique and significant in the way one operates in a school. In order for a teacher to be effective, they need to provide instruction, whilst being emotionally accessible to their students as it helps with interpersonal connection. However, counsellors are therapists and have a very different professional relationship with their clients. For counsellors to be effective for their clients, they are required to exercise good boundaries and have limited contact in the scope of the goals of counselling. Hence, by lumping these two significantly different roles essentially muddles up the role of a teacher or counsellor, thereby inhibiting the effectiveness of either role. Coupled with the added stress of needing to train to be an ‚Äúeffective‚Äù counsellor, whilst being a competent teacher, we may have introduced an insurmountable layer of psychological stress for the teacher needing to play multiple roles over and above an already stressful occupation, despite news of reducing their workload. It‚Äôs like telling a mother or father that they need to take on the role of their spouse in addition to their current role ‚Äî is it possible to lessen one‚Äôs workload to mitigate the stressful situation? The solution will have to be an explicit and separate role for teachers and counsellors. Perhaps it‚Äôs better to go back to the drawing board and consult our professional bodies like the @singaporepsychologicalsociety before being reactive to the notion of being ‚Äòill-equipped‚Äô.
.
Read the full article via @straits_times @ https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/parenting-education/students-prefer-their-teachers-to-counsellors-for-mental-health
.

description:
[do you have Zoom Fatigue?] 'Zoom fatigue' may be with us for years. Here's how we'll cope.
.
Too many video conferences can lead to what is now nicknamed "Zoom fatigue." New research shows how employers and tech companies can maintain the positive aspects of remote work while reducing the psychological drain, particularly for women.
.
The article describes ‚Äúhypergaze,‚Äù an intense feeling that the other people on the call are staring at you, because the video conferencing display shows everyone looking toward their cameras no matter who their focus is actually on. It‚Äôs even worse in one-on-one meetings, when your colleague‚Äôs face appears so large on the screen, it‚Äôs as if they are standing less than two feet away.
.
‚ÄúThis kind of physical proximity that is mimicked by video conference is perceived by the brain as a situation that would lead either to mating or to conflict,‚Äù says Fauville. ‚ÄúThis is very intense for the brain.‚Äù
.
Full article via @natgeo @ https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/article/zoom-fatigue-may-be-with-us-for-years-heres-how-well-cope
.

description:
[on other mental health fronts] Simone Biles withdraws from Olympics all-around gymnastics ‚Äî Simone Biles' dramatic exit from the Olympic team gymnastics final over concerns for her mental health could be a catalyst for wider change, experts say.
.
"We wholeheartedly support Simone's decision and applaud her bravery in prioritising her well-being," the statement said. 
.
"Her courage shows, yet again, why she is a role model for so many."
.
Biles' decision to pull out of the all-around comes after her stunning withdrawal early in Tuesday's team final in Tokyo.
.
The 24-year-old superstar - one of the faces of the Olympics - abruptly scratched from the competition after one rotation citing mental health concerns.
.
No matter the context, your mental health matters! Now more than ever, your concerns are legitimate.
.

Join host Steven Chia as he speaks to mental health experts, TPP Clinical Psychologist Dr Shawn Ee, Exec Dir THK FSC Dr Nicodemus Lim, Former school counsellor Mr Gary Koh, and youth representative, Project: It‚Äôll Be Alright, Ms Hasyimah Jasni, as they discuss how we can deal with the trauma, and what more can we do for our students. .

.
Her comments come the same day Education Minister Chan Chun Sing announced that he will deliver a ministerial statement in Parliament next week to address the support given to schools and students in need following the River Valley High incident.

I‚Äôm a firm proponent of equal parenting and house management in situations where both parents are working. It makes me chuckle a little when someone praises my husband for being so hands-on. Sure appreciation is merited but not because he is helping me out but because he is fulfilling his responsibility to equally care for the baby and our home. I understand where this old school thinking is coming from but a lot has changed since then and perspectives should too. 

It‚Äôs an obsolete concept where moms are considered the primary caregiver unless the couple has decided for one of them to be a stay-at-home parent, I say parent because it can either be the mom or the dad. In our case, I feel my husband is better suited to be a SAHD if given the choice because he is more patient and a homebody. 

I see mixed feedback where other fathers are happily doing their part with this equal parenting while some can do more. And that‚Äôs okay because parenting is a learning journey. No one is perfect and that transcends to being a parent. Parenthood is tough but what matters is the love, care and attention we put in for our child, our spouse and the family in totality.

So thank you @neoquadra for being an awesome dad. We love you and hope you never get tired of feeding, bathing, caring, playing, talking and reading books to our son, @howisethan. Like I mentioned to you during his first week of existence, you are doing great! 

Appreciating and celebrating all the fathers and father figures out there because they deserve it too!

Curious! Do you prefer that both parents work or one be a SAHM / SAHD? 
‚Ä¢

description:
[our condolences to those afflicted] If you have just tuned into the news, please take care that you may be triggered by the recent horrific news: A 13-year-old Secondary 1 student of River Valley High School was killed on campus on July 19, allegedly by a 16-year-old Secondary 4 student.
.
Our heart goes out to the families on both sides, and others in the immediate vicinity who were afflicted. We have particular concern for the student who has to deal with his act for the rest of his life, not to mention his mental health and psychological response to the aftermath of the situation. This is considered to be a traumatic and stressful event on all fronts, which can stir up hurts, losses and fear in the community. We wish to say that the authorities are doing the best they can to ensure everyone‚Äôs ongoing safety and implore the greater public to respect the privacy of both families by not sensationalising these acts and making fun of the facts of the case.
.

Superheroes need their superheroes too

Why do we love superheroes so much? I like to think it‚Äôs because we all need a bit of rescuing from time to time. Whether you were bullied at the playground or workplace, or experienced extremes of severe trauma in your life, we had all encountered ordeals where we wished we had been rescued. But superheroes need rescuing too - they face grief, personal tragedies, moral dilemmas and no-win scenarios - but they also show us how we can cope in the face of insurmountable odds. 

I am no superhero, despite the hashtag #docbydaysuperherobynight I wish I were - but no amount of gamma radiation, or superhuman serum, is going to turn me into one. I use humour as my "superpower" though - as I firmly believe that laughter is the best medicine. 

But trauma is no laughing matter.

I recently learnt that two-thirds of people in Singapore have experienced at least one traumatic event during the first 18 years of their lives, and that in 2020, @msfcares handled significantly more child abuse cases compared to the preceding 6 years. Growing up with considerable trauma can cause them to project these negative emotions into their own actions - most times at a subconscious level. It is thus on us as a caring society to be aware of these trauma and how it can impact on the community‚Äôs mental health. We must better identify the at-risk population by being more trauma-informed, in order to provide support to these victims, or to direct them to seek professional help.

Remember. Clowns cry too, and sometimes the widest grins can hide the saddest tears. These persons could be anyone around you. And it might even be you. 

@SafeCircle.SG (https://www.safecircle.sg ) comprises 7 local agencies that focus on community-based mental health services for children and youths. The platform provides help in coping with trauma, and also equips us with the resources to offer help to someone in need. As a parent, educator, helping professional or even just a concerned peer, check out their complimentary programs and workshops to integrate trauma-informed care into our work and lives. 

#SafeCircleSG

description:
[did you know?] The Danger of Mindfulness ‚Äî The facts about mindfulness no one's talking about.
.
Mindfulness has become over-hyped, misunderstood, and overly commodified. The documented robust health effects are overstated and not enough health professionals are talking about the unknowns or downsides. There are other ways to self-soothe besides mindfulness; it's one of many tools in the toolbox. We know there is no substitute for good old psychotherapy. Your needs are always kept in mind.
.

Even the strong, happy and confident ones amongst us may be hiding emotional scars sustained in our youth. Even the bully, oppressor and perpetrator could have adverse childhood experiences that contributed to their manifestations. 

Trauma comes in many forms and traumatic events include anything from being bullied in school, parental divorce, sudden loss of a loved one, witnessed or experienced domestic violence, to sexual harassment or abuse.

I was quite stunned to find out that nearly 64% of people in Singapore have reported experiencing at least one traumatic event during the first 18 years of their lives. It is also worrying to read that in 2020, @msfcares handled 44.6% more child abuse cases compared to 6 years before. 

Growing up with trauma can cause victims to project their trauma unto their actions. Hence, it is important for us as a society to be aware of trauma and how it relates to mental health. Being more trauma-informed, we can then better identify the vulnerable population, provide support and care to distressed victims, or encourage them to seek professional help if needed. 

@SafeCircle.SG (https://www.safecircle.sg ) comprises 7 local agencies that focus on community-based mental health services for children and youths. The platform provides help in coping with trauma, and also equips us with the resources to offer help to someone in need. As a parent, educator, helping professional or even just a concerned peer, check out their complimentary programs and workshops to integrate trauma-informed care into our work and lives. 

#SafeCircleSG #mentalhealth #psychologicalhealth #emotionalhealth #mentalhealthsupport #mentalwellness #mentalwellbeing #emotionalwellness #trauma #mentaltrauma #psychologicaltrauma #childhoodtrauma #adversechildhoodexperiences #childabuse #traumainformed #traumainformedcare #traumaawareness #traumahealing #selfcare #feelsafe #peersupport #helpinghand

@accesets @boystownsg @campuspsy.sg @calsingapore @we.are.limitless @samhsingapore @sgchildrensoc @mercurysocial

[ANGER management? We need it from early on] Don‚Äôt teach your child NOT to be angry ‚Äî Teach them HOW to be angry.
.
Let‚Äôs not deceive ourselves parents! Learning to manage our feelings start from early on as developmentally age-appropriate milestones. Anger is just one of the many feelings we have that is necessary for our aggressive manifestations necessary for behavioural regulation and the building blocks for learning assertiveness. If we are afraid to deal with our own anger or express it in a useful way, it is almost inevitable that our children will struggle with being able to do so. Guess where they would have internalised these emotional regulation dynamics from? So, let‚Äôs start from the beginning. By showing our children how they can express their anger confidently and communicatively, it will help them in ways that pay exponential dividends psychologically and interpersonally. Don‚Äôt squander it away by discouraging their display of anger or worse, to suppress or ‚Äògaslight‚Äô their incendiary experiences. Remember, suppressed emotions will always come back in uglier ways. Your needs are always kept in mind.
.

[just in] Look on the bright side ‚Äî you and your families now get to enjoy a more relaxed and intimate wedding that truly celebrates the idea of marriage.
.
THERE‚ÄôS MORE TO MARRIAGE THAN THE BIG DAY
Ms Lynette Tan, a Clinical Psychologist at The Psychology Practice, says that holding a wedding during these times can present an opportunity for couples to reflect on what the occasion means to them. ‚ÄúThey can ask themselves if there is the pressure of having to conform to certain practices that may not actually be meaningful to them as a couple. Instead, they can think about how the wedding can be conducted in a way that is more representative of who they are or even consider personalising the experience for their guests, which may be hard to do on a larger scale. ‚ÄòSmaller scale‚Äô does not mean it has to be any less memorable.‚Äù
.
KEEP CALM AND MARRY ON!
If you are disappointed and/or frustrated with changes to your wedding plans, Ms Lynette Tan suggests that you tune in to how you feel, and be kind to yourself and your partner. Also, it is vital to talk it out ‚Äî after all, the pandemic can understandably lead to worries such as financial security, or starting a family. Find an appropriate time to have conversations about these issues. When your partner shares his or her feelings, respond gently. Recognise that it‚Äôs normal to feel some pressure.
.
Full article via @channelnewsasia @ https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/brandstudio/ffl-istilldo/look-on-the-bright-side-you-and-your-families-now-get-to-enjoy-a-14477854

[TPP speaks] Residents say they are physically healthier than before Covid-19 Helplines ‚Äî But nearly 25% report a decline in mental health, with money woes top cause of anxiety, depression.
.
PANDEMIC HAS DISRUPTED PEOPLE'S LIVES
‚ÄúCovid-19 is an abnormal event that interrupts our way of life... Any major lifestyle change that removes a coping strategy for stress can tip someone over into feeling trapped. For example, avid gym-goers would struggle when gyms are closed.‚Äù
.
DR SHAWN EE,
director of The Psychology Practice.
.
Although nearly a quarter of respondents reported suffering from anxiety and depression in the past year, 68 per cent believe there is a stigma against mental health issues in Singapore.
.
More than 65 per cent would avoid the topic with their family, even when there is an issue.
.
Dr Shawn Ee, said this decline in mental health was not surprising: "Covid-19 is an abnormal event that interrupts our way of life.‚Äù
.
